title: In The Great Gatsby, what does Gatsby's car represent? - Quora
tags: Literature of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Like his house and his clothes, the car shows both Gatsby’s wealth and his poor taste in the way he displays that wealth. Read carefully the description of his clothes when he arrives at Nick’s door for tea with Daisy. No one raised in wealth would dress that way. Gatsby is nouveau riche (new money); he has money, whether it is really his or his masters’, but he has no understanding of the “right” way (“rich not gaudy,” as Polonius advises his son, Laertes) to spend it. Tom describes the car as a circus wagon. As a plot device, the gaudiness of the car makes it easy for Wilson to recognize as the “murder” weapon.
